conclusion: Shadows are influenced by the position of the light source relative to the objects and the ground.
In the first image, the light source is positioned in front of the objects, casting shadows (A, B, C, and D) toward the back.
The shadows are relatively short and positioned directly behind the objects.
When the light source moves to the back right, shadows will be cast toward the front left.
The size of the shadows will change depending on the distance between the light source and the objects.
If the light source moves farther away, shadows become longer; if it moves closer, shadows become shorter.
Shadow A (Nail) moves from behind the nail to the front left.
Shadow A (Nail) becomes longer because the nail is tall and the light source is now positioned lower and farther away.
Shadow B (Cake) moves from behind the cake to the front left.
Shadow B (Cake) becomes slightly longer due to the change in light direction, but the cake's relatively flat shape limits the shadow's elongation.
Shadow C (Medical Roll) moves from behind the medical roll to the front left.
Shadow C (Medical Roll) becomes longer because the roll has a larger vertical dimension, and the light source is farther away.
Shadow D (Ring) moves from behind the ring to the front left.
Shadow D (Ring) remains small and circular because the ring is flat and does not have significant height to cast a long shadow.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) move to the front left when the light source moves to the back right.
Shadow D (Ring) remains small and circular.
